In Julia, Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

Certainly! Below is a Julia function named `wrap_string` that takes a string and wraps the text so that each line does not exceed the specified `text_width`. If `text_width` is not provided, it defaults to 10 characters.

```julia
function wrap_string(str::String, text_width::Int=10)
    words = split(str)
    current_line_length = 0
    wrapped_text = ""

    for word in words
        word_length = length(word)
        # Check if adding the next word would exceed the line width
        if current_line_length + word_length > text_width
            # Start a new line if the word would exceed the line width
            wrapped_text *= "\n"
            current_line_length = 0
        end
        # Add a space before the word if it's not the beginning of a line
        if current_line_length > 0
            wrapped_text *= " "
            current_line_length += 1  # Account for the space
        end
        wrapped_text *= word
        current_line_length += word_length
    end

    return wrapped_text
end

# Example usage:
text = "The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog"
wrapped_text = wrap_string(text)
println(wrapped_text)
```

When you run this code with the provided example, it will output the string with new lines inserted so that no line is longer than 10 characters:

```
The quick
brown fox
jumps over
the lazy
dog
```

Keep in mind that this function does not break words. If a single word is longer than `text_width`, it will be placed on a new line but will not be split into smaller parts. If you need to handle longer words, you would need to modify the function to include additional logic to split words that exceed the `text_width`.
